items.title: Marokko-tegenstander Tanzania schrijft historie in Afrika Cup
items.summary: Tanzania heeft een record gevestigd door zich met slechts twee punten in de groepsfase te kwalificeren voor de achtste finales van de Africa Cup. De tegenstander van Marokko in de knock-outfase werd daarmee een van de beste nummers drie.

items.title: Manager Celtic vreest niet voor zijn baan na nieuwe sof
items.summary: De aanstelling van Wilfriend Nancy heeft Celtic nog niet de gewenste resultaten gebracht. Dinsdagavond verloor de Schotse topclub de vijfde wedstrijd onder zijn leiding sinds zijn aanstelling begin december. Rangers komt met rasse schreden dichter bij en supporters willen de thuiswedstrijd zaterdag boycotten.

items.title: Haaland staat open voor Brits paspoort: 'Ik voel me hier thuis'
items.summary: Erling Haaland zou geen 'nee' zeggen tegen een Brits paspoort. Heel veel meer dan een paar praktische zaken zou de Noorse superspits van Manchester City er niet aan hebben, maar het zou wel een cirkel rond maken.

items.title: Ambitieus Coventry City wil investeren in selectie en Lampard
items.summary: De eigenaar van Coventry City, Doug King, is van plan om trainer Frank Lampard volgende maand te steunen met een aanzienlijk transferbudget. De club jaagt op een terugkeer naar de Premier League na 25 jaar en is daarnaast bereid om gesprekken te openen over een nieuw contract voor de trainer.

items.title: Veltman blinkt uit bij Brighton, Welbeck krijgt steun ondanks gemiste panenka
items.summary: Zo'n anderhalf jaar na zijn laatste doelpunt in de Premier League was Jo√´l Veltman weer eens trefzeker voor Brighton & Hove Albion. De bijna 34-jarige verdediger bezorgde zijn ploeg daarmee een punt bij West Ham United, terwijl Danny Welbeck ondanks een rake strafschop de wind van voren kreeg na een gemiste panenka.

items.title: Clarke Q&A in full: World Cup 'vindication', Barnes talks, USA plans & more
items.summary: In a wide-ranging interview, Steve Clarke reflects on Scotland qualifying for the World Cup for the first time since 1998, his plans for the USA, talks with Newcastle Utd's Harvey Barnes and much more...

items.title: January transfer window 2026: what every Premier League club needs
items.summary: Aston Villa have a decision to make about Harvey Elliott, Brentford have money to spend and Burnley and Everton need goalscorers A busy summer with the arrival of more than ¬£250m in reinforcements has proved to be invaluable given the number of injuries that have hit Arsenal, particularly in defence. But that also makes any more expensive incomings unlikely in January, especially after the timely return of the influential Gabriel Magalh√£es this week. A loan signing or two could be on the cards, however, with Arsenal not having filled either slot so far after bringing in Neto from Bournemouth and Raheem Sterling from Chelsea last season. Mikel Arteta could do with more cover at right-back and must also decide whether to allow Ethan Nwaneri to go on loan with the 18-year-old having made only three starts in all competitions. Ed Aarons Continue reading...

items.title: From breakups to contract minefields: it‚Äôs make or break time for academy players
items.summary: Young footballers have big decisions to make at this time of year as academy directors aim to sign the most talented Any 15- or 16-year-olds who should be revising for their mock GCSEs are probably finding that the end of December is a testing time of year. For those in academy football, it can often be make or break. While the very best ‚Äì such as Arsenal‚Äôs record-breaking Max Dowman, who made headlines in October when he agreed terms on a scholarship deal ‚Äì secured their futures in good time, many discovered their fates just before the 31 December deadline. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs always the sort of classic breakup. It‚Äôs not you, it‚Äôs us,‚Äù says Dr Chris Platts, who has studied the academy system for more than a decade and offers support to young players and their families. ‚ÄúBeing released before Christmas isn‚Äôt nice for a kid. Then they‚Äôve got about five months before their GCSEs and those five months are now going to include a lot of trials and uncertainty going into the following year.‚Äù Continue reading...

items.title: Clarke reveals 'vindication' after criticism, World Cup plans and Barnes talks
items.summary: Scotland head coach Steve Clarke ended 2024 with some fans criticising his style of play, squad selection and more following a winless Euros campaign in Germany.

items.title: Former Australia cricketer Martyn in coma with meningitis
items.summary: Former Australia batter Damien Martyn has been placed in an induced coma after contracting meningitis.

items.title: Tyrrhenian Sea seeks second Quebec Stakes win at Lingfield
items.summary: Lingfield takes centre stage this afternoon, with Listed action in the Quebec Stakes headlining the all-weather card at 2pm.

items.title: Arsenal go 5 clear in 'great way to end the year'
items.summary: Mikel Arteta labeled Arsenal's 4-1 thrashing of Aston Villa a "great way to end the year," but played down the importance of his team moving five points clear at the top of the Premier League.

items.title: Chelsea defend Palmer sub amid boos at Bridge
items.summary: Chelsea assistant coach Willy Caballero defended the decision to take off Cole Palmer during the 2-2 draw with Bournemouth after supporters at Stamford Bridge reacted furiously to Enzo Maresca's substitution.

items.title: Emery denies Arteta snub after Arsenal beat Villa
items.summary: Unai Emery rejected claims that he snubbed Arsenal boss Mikel Arteta after the full-time whistle in Aston Villa's clash at the Emirates Stadium.

items.title: Wolves draw sums up Man Utd's year: Hope followed by howlers
items.summary: Any momentum generated by Man United's Boxing Day win over Newcastle was brought to a shuddering halt on Tuesday -- this time by the worst side in the division.

items.title: After emphatic win over title rivals, Arsenal can dare to dream once more
items.summary: Concern had been building, but Arsenal's triumph sends them surging into the New Year.

items.title: Rampant Arsenal make a strong title statement and bury the Emery bogey | John Brewin
items.summary: The fluent football of autumn returned against an Aston Villa team who have often caused Arteta‚Äôs side problems Should Arsenal lift the Premier League trophy in May, the thrill of the chase will be remembered fondly, difficult forks in the road glorified. Here was a statement win to show that the pain and agony can be worth it. A champion team must often suffer to arrive at beautiful moments. Those scratchy wins over Wolves, Everton and Brighton can now be celebrated alongside a champagne evening to sign off 2025. The club‚Äôs familiarity with chasing the title as the league turns for home has bred an unavoidable anxiety. April and May have previously proved the cruellest months but December has been full of worries. In pre-match, ‚Äúnorth London forever‚Äù was sung tremulously, fans seeking a collective warmth to ward off individual doubts about the dream. For 45 minutes, fans, players and manager alike were left alone with their private agonies, only for the second half where Arsenal played the expansive, confident football of the autumn, smashing in four goals to vaporise the unease. Continue reading...

items.title: Dundee United climb back into top six with victory at Livingston
items.summary: Dundee United moved back into the Scottish Premiership top six with a deserved 3-1 win at basement side Livingston.

items.title: Bournemouth draw with Chelsea after chaotic first half
items.summary: Bournemouth are winless against Chelsea in their last nine Premier League matches after drawing 2-2 at Stamford Bridge.

items.title: Wolves earn shock draw at Man Utd to end losing run
items.summary: Ladislav Krejci equaliser earns Wolverhampton Wanderers their first point since October as they draw 1-1 at Manchester United.
